First, we need to understand what the twenty-third Amendment to the US Constitution is about. The twenty-third Amendment, ratified in 1961, grants residents of Washington D.C. the right to vote in presidential elections. Prior to this amendment, residents of Washington D.C. did not have the right to vote for the President and Vice President of the United States.

Next, we need to understand the timeline of Harry Truman's presidency. Harry Truman was the 33rd President of the United States and served from 1945 to 1953. This means that Truman's presidency started more than a decade before the twenty-third Amendment was ratified in 1961.

Therefore, we can conclude that Harry Truman's presidency was not affected by the twenty-third Amendment as it was ratified after his term as President had ended. So the correct answer is (A) yes, his presidency was unaffected by the twenty-third Amendment.

Therefore, during Truman's presidency, the twenty-third Amendment did not exist and did not affect his presidency. 

Therefore, the correct answer is (A) yes, Harry Truman's presidency was unaffected by the twenty-third Amendment to the US Constitution since it was not ratified until after his presidency.

D.C. residents did not have the right to vote in presidential elections during his time in office, so this amendment would not have impacted his presidency in any way.
